by nothing sacred or
trivial, but simply our bodies

that gazes at me
as I gaze at them.
I'm the magician (in satin and velvet. You gaze at his splendor with eyes you've not used yet...)

as you study their gaze out in the open

but then such a flash from the stage that your gaze falters
AND ONLY THEN DO WE RECOGNIZE

history.p: This story was originally entitled 'love.' On the very first notes page, I have, "magician, sparkles, splendor, new eyes (Sunny Goodge St. [Judi Collins]), sound, revealing truth despite its pain, the shrinking of the self and expanding of the self to reach the "you are I" and "I am you" simultaneously. "play/sport/caress", rolling I was mistaken and, am alas, alone. "I know loss" two triangles, sang in harmony. has "we" (w/implication of joined units--two lovers, allies in a war, saying it when the person spoken to is included in the "we") "[looked (up) with a happiness smiling) look]" you are my complement so yes; how far you'll let others 'in' how far you assume allowed entrance; monochrome overload."
Much later in my first notebook there is titled 'on love' which is crossed out and replaced with "Love is not":
history.blockquote:
It has been argued by Alyssa that love can be only one of two undesirables. It is either an obsession in ignorance, thus an emotion with no knowledge to be rational, or a dependance and thus a preison. If it is not either of these things, the kindest, most idealistic examiner does not call it love (and nor will anyone else). If this is true I shall be very depressed, and so, though perhaps that is the only thing to d, I will argue to postpone it, and perhaps find a secret escape route.
The first posibility is a passion that hardly seems to be a useful situation for anyone. I will explore it later, but hope to fid, that it is not love, but is a vessel for finding true love, and thus does possess some utility.
The second possibility sounds like a curse for us all to avoid. But I have some questions. I depend upon my arms ad legs for many things. In using them, few people will claim I am stupidly being oppressed by physical crutches. Were I to lose them, I would feel a great loss and any substitute would feel inadequate. I would want my arms and legs back.
Cat Stevens--Moon Shadow): _I_ do not love my arms.
...(see my email to her [Alyssa])
So dependingship is worth reeiving as many are better companions then ourselves to ourselves.
Life we live, and as participants we are winners. Love is similar, alas, it is not spoon fed to us as life is. Does it require labour? We work for colour?
